pageProps.contentHtml:
Baire category theorem, Lp spaces
  1. Let fff be a positive continuous function on R\RR such that lim⁡∣t∣→∞f(t)=0\lim_{\abs{t}\to\infty} f\p{t} = 0lim∣t∣→∞​f(t)=0. Show that the set {hf∣h∈L1(R), ∥h∥L1≤K}\set{hf \mid h \in L^1\p{\R},\ \norm{h}_{L^1} \leq K}{hf∣h∈L1(R), ∥h∥L1​≤K} is a closed nowhere dense set in L1(R)L^1\p{\R}L1(R) for any K≥1K \geq 1K≥1.
  2. Let {fn}n\set{f_n}_n{fn​}n​ be a sequence of positive continuous functions on R\RR such that for each nnn we have lim⁡∣t∣→∞fn(t)=0\lim_{\abs{t}\to\infty} f_n\p{t} = 0lim∣t∣→∞​fn​(t)=0. Show that there exists g∈L1(R)g \in L^1\p{\R}g∈L1(R) such that gfn∉L1(R)\frac{g}{f_n} \notin L^1\p{\R}fn​g​∈/L1(R) for all nnn.
Solution.

  1. Let EK={hf∣h∈L1(R), ∥h∥L1≤K}E_K = \set{hf \mid h \in L^1\p{\R},\ \norm{h}_{L^1} \leq K}EK​={hf∣h∈L1(R), ∥h∥L1​≤K}, and suppose {hnf}n⊆EK\set{h_nf}_n \subseteq E_K{hn​f}n​⊆EK​ is a sequence of functions which converges to some ggg in L1(R)L^1\p{\R}L1(R). Since fff is non-zero, we see that hn→gf≕hh_n \to \frac{g}{f} \eqqcolon hhn​→fg​=:h pointwise. Thus, by Fatou's lemma,

    ∥h∥L1≤lim inf⁡n→∞ ∥hn∥L1≤K  ⟹  hf∈EK.\norm{h}_{L^1} \leq \liminf_{n\to\infty}\,\norm{h_n}_{L^1} \leq K \implies hf \in E_K.∥h∥L1​≤n→∞liminf​∥hn​∥L1​≤K⟹hf∈EK​.

    Finally, by Hölder's inequality, because fff is vanishes at infinity, it is bounded, which gives

    ∥hf∥L1≤∥h∥L1∥f∥L∞≤K∥f∥L∞<∞,\norm{hf}_{L^1} \leq \norm{h}_{L^1} \norm{f}_{L^\infty} \leq K \norm{f}_{L^\infty} < \infty,∥hf∥L1​≤∥h∥L1​∥f∥L∞​≤K∥f∥L∞​<∞,

    so EKE_KEK​ is a closed subset of L1(R)L^1\p{\R}L1(R). For the second claim, let hf∈EKhf \in E_Khf∈EK​ and ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0. We need to find g∈L1(R)g \in L^1\p{\R}g∈L1(R) which approximates hfhfhf well in L1(R)L^1\p{\R}L1(R) but has ∥gf∥L1>K\norm{\frac{g}{f}}_{L^1} > K∥∥​fg​∥∥​L1​>K. For constants 0<R<M0 < R < M0<R<M which we will choose, consider

    g=hfχB(0,R)+(K+1)fχ[M,M+1].g = hf\chi_{B\p{0,R}} + \p{K + 1}f\chi_{\br{M, M+1}}.g=hfχB(0,R)​+(K+1)fχ[M,M+1]​.

    We choose this form since we can approximate hfhfhf very well by ggg, but still have issues in the second term after dividing by fff. Since hf∈L1(R)hf \in L^1\p{\R}hf∈L1(R), we may pick R>0R > 0R>0 so large so that ∥hfχB(0,R)c∥L1<ε\norm{hf\chi_{B\p{0,R}^\comp}}_{L^1} < \epsilon∥∥​hfχB(0,R)c​∥∥​L1​<ε. Pick M>RM > RM>R so large so that ∣f(t)∣≤εK+1\abs{f\p{t}} \leq \frac{\epsilon}{K + 1}∣f(t)∣≤K+1ε​ for t≥Mt \geq Mt≥M. Then

    ∥hf−g∥L1≤∥hfχB(0,R)c∥L1+(K+1)∥fχ[M,M+1]∥L∞∥χ[M,M+1]∥L1≤ε+(K+1)εK+1=2ε,\begin{aligned} \norm{hf - g}_{L^1} &\leq \norm{hf_{\chi_{B\p{0,R}^\comp}}}_{L^1} + \p{K + 1}\norm{f\chi_{\br{M,M+1}}}_{L^\infty} \norm{\chi_{\br{M,M+1}}}_{L^1} \\ &\leq \epsilon + \p{K + 1} \frac{\epsilon}{K + 1} \\ &= 2\epsilon, \end{aligned}∥hf−g∥L1​​≤∥∥​hfχB(0,R)c​​∥∥​L1​+(K+1)∥∥​fχ[M,M+1]​∥∥​L∞​∥∥​χ[M,M+1]​∥∥​L1​≤ε+(K+1)K+1ε​=2ε,​

    but

    ∥gf∥L1≥(K+1)∥χ[M,M+1]∥=K+1>K,\norm{\frac{g}{f}}_{L^1} \geq \p{K + 1}\norm{\chi_{\br{M,M+1}}} = K + 1 > K,∥∥​fg​∥∥​L1​≥(K+1)∥∥​χ[M,M+1]​∥∥​=K+1>K,

    so g∉EKg \notin E_Kg∈/EK​. Thus, EKE_KEK​ is a closed, nowhere dense subset of L1(R)L^1\p{\R}L1(R).

  2. Since L1(R)L^1\p{\R}L1(R) is complete, the Baire category theorem tells us that

    L1(R)≠⋃n,K∈N{hfn∣h∈L1(R), ∥h∥L1≤K}.L^1\p{\R} \neq \bigcup_{n, K \in \N} \set{hf_n \mid h \in L^1\p{\R},\ \norm{h}_{L^1} \leq K}.L1(R)=n,K∈N⋃​{hfn​∣h∈L1(R), ∥h∥L1​≤K}.

    Thus, there exists g∈L1(R)g \in L^1\p{\R}g∈L1(R), which is not in the right-hand side, i.e., for all n,K∈Nn, K \in \Nn,K∈N, we have gfn∉L1(R)\frac{g}{f_n} \notin L^1\p{\R}fn​g​∈/L1(R) or ∥g∥L1>K\norm{g}_{L^1} > K∥g∥L1​>K. Thus, if we fix KKK large enough, we know that ∥g∥L1≤K\norm{g}_{L^1} \leq K∥g∥L1​≤K, which means that gfn∉L1(R)\frac{g}{f_n} \notin L^1\p{\R}fn​g​∈/L1(R) for all nnn.
